Combinatorial Reconfiguration Bibliography

This interactive web bibliography on Combinatorial Reconfiguration is created from a Zotero collection of Duc A. Hoang using a forked version of davidswelt/zot_bib_web with slight modification.
  • 2021 (1)
  • 2020 (51)
  • 2019 (63)
  • 2018 (57)
  • 2017 (56)
  • 2016 (34)
  • 2015 (38)
  • 2014 (35)
  • 2013 (13)
  • 2012 (7)
  • –2011 (41)
  • Journal Articles (118)
  • Conference and Workshop Papers (79)
  • Book Chapters (2)
  • Theses (12)
  • Technical Reports (14)
  • Talks (50)
  • Video Recordings (5)
  • Blog Posts (5)
  • Manuscripts (111)
 

2021

Feghali, Carl (2021). Reconfiguring colorings of graphs with bounded maximum average degree. Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series B, 147, 133–138. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jctb.2020.11.001

2020

PDF
Hoang, Duc A., Suzuki, Akira, & Yagita, Tsuyoshi (2020). Reconfiguring $k$-path Vertex Covers. In M. Sohel Rahman, Kunihiko Sadakane, & Wing-Kin Sung (Eds.), WALCOM: Algorithms and Computation (pp. 133–145). https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-39881-1_12
QCKEY74Y year__2020 type__conferencePaper "Combinatorial Reconfiguration" "Computational complexity" "Polynomial-time algorithms" "k-path vertex cover" "𝙿𝚂𝙿𝙰𝙲𝙴PSPACE\mathtt {PSPACE}-completeness"
BIB
@inproceedings{hoang2020reconfiguring, address = {Cham}, series = {Lecture {Notes} in {Computer} {Science}}, title = {Reconfiguring \$k\$-path {Vertex} {Covers}}, copyright = {All rights reserved}, isbn = {978-3-030-39881-1}, url = {https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-030-39881-1_12}, doi = {10.1007/978-3-030-39881-1_12}, 𝖳𝖩TJ{\textbackslash}mathsf \{TJ\}, and 𝖳𝖠𝖱TAR{\textbackslash}mathsf \{TAR\}. The problem for 𝑘=2k=2k=2, known as the Vertex Cover Reconfiguration (VCR) problem, has been well-studied in the literature. We show that certain known hardness results for VCR on different graph classes including planar graphs, bounded bandwidth graphs, chordal graphs, and bipartite graphs, can be extended for k -PVCR. In particular, we prove a complexity dichotomy for k -PVCR on general graphs: on those whose maximum degree is 3 (and even planar), the problem is 𝙿𝚂𝙿𝙰𝙲𝙴PSPACE{\textbackslash}mathtt \{PSPACE\}-complete, while on those whose maximum degree is 2 (i.e., paths and cycles), the problem can be solved in polynomial time. Additionally, we also design polynomial-time algorithms for k -PVCR on trees under each of 𝖳𝖩TJ{\textbackslash}mathsf \{TJ\} and 𝖳𝖠𝖱TAR{\textbackslash}mathsf \{TAR\}. Moreover, on paths, cycles, and trees, we describe how one can construct a reconfiguration sequence between two given k-path vertex covers in a yes-instance. In particular, on paths, our constructed reconfiguration sequence is shortest.}, language = {en}, booktitle = {{WALCOM}: {Algorithms} and {Computation}}, publisher = {Springer International Publishing}, author = {Hoang, Duc A. and Suzuki, Akira and Yagita, Tsuyoshi}, editor = {Rahman, M. Sohel and Sadakane, Kunihiko and Sung, Wing-Kin}, year = {2020}, keywords = {Combinatorial Reconfiguration, Computational complexity, Polynomial-time algorithms, k-path vertex cover, 𝙿𝚂𝙿𝙰𝙲𝙴PSPACE{\textbackslash}mathtt \{PSPACE\}-completeness}, pages = {133--145}, }
link

Akitaya, Hugo A., Korman, Matias, Korten, Oliver, Souvaine, Diane L., & Tóth, Csaba D. (2020). Reconfiguration of Connected Graph Partitions via Recombination. Retrieved from http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.07378
arXiv: 2011.07378
QCKEY74Y year__2020 type__manuscript "Computer Science - Computational Complexity" "Computer Science - Data Structures and Algorithms" "Computer Science - Discrete Mathematics"
BIB
@unpublished{akitaya2020reconfiguration, title = {Reconfiguration of {Connected} {Graph} {Partitions} via {Recombination}}, url = {http://arxiv.org/abs/2011.07378}, denoted {\textbackslash}emph\{\$(k,s)\$-BCP\}, is a partition of \$V(G)\$ into \$k\$ nonempty subsets, of sizes \$n\_1,{\textbackslash}ldots , n\_k\$ with \${\textbar}n\_i-n/k{\textbar}{\textbackslash}leq s\$, each of which induces a connected subgraph (when \$s=0\$, the \$k\$ parts are perfectly balanced, and we call it {\textbackslash}emph\{\$k\$-BCP\} for short). A {\textbackslash}emph\{recombination\} is an operation that takes a \$(k,s)\$-BCP of a graph \$G\$ and produces another by merging two adjacent subgraphs and repartitioning them. Given two \$k\$-BCPs, \$A\$ and \$B\$, of \$G\$ and a slack \$s{\textbackslash}geq 0\$, we wish to determine whether there exists a sequence of recombinations that transform \$A\$ into \$B\$ via \$(k,s)\$-BCPs. We obtain four results related to this problem: (1) When \$s\$ is unbounded, the transformation is always possible using at most \$6(k-1)\$ recombinations. (2) If \$G\$ is Hamiltonian, the transformation is possible using \$O(kn)\$ recombinations for any \$s {\textbackslash}ge n/k\$, and (3) we provide negative instances for \$s {\textbackslash}leq n/(3k)\$. (4) We show that the problem is PSPACE-complete when \$k {\textbackslash}in O(n{\textasciicircum}\{{\textbackslash}varepsilon\})\$ and \$s {\textbackslash}in O(n{\textasciicircum}\{1-{\textbackslash}varepsilon\})\$, for any constant \$0 {\textless} {\textbackslash}varepsilon {\textbackslash}le 1\$, even for restricted settings such as when \$G\$ is an edge-maximal planar graph or when \$k=3\$ and \$G\$ is planar.}, urldate = {2020-11-25}, author = {Akitaya, Hugo A. and Korman, Matias and Korten, Oliver and Souvaine, Diane L. and Tóth, Csaba D.}, month = nov, year = {2020}, note = {arXiv: 2011.07378}, keywords = {Computer Science - Computational Complexity, Computer Science - Data Structures and Algorithms, Computer Science - Discrete Mathematics}, }
link
PDF

Bousquet, Nicolas, Joffard, Alice, & Ouvrard, Paul (2020). Linear transformations between dominating sets in the TAR-model. Retrieved from http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.16726
arXiv: 2006.16726
QCKEY74Y year__2020 type__manuscript "Computer Science - Data Structures and Algorithms" "Computer Science - Discrete Mathematics"
BIB
@unpublished{bousquet2020linear, title = {Linear transformations between dominating sets in the {TAR}-model}, url = {http://arxiv.org/abs/2006.16726}, D\_1 {\textbackslash}ldots, D\_{\textbackslash}ell = D\_\{{\textbackslash}sf t\} {\textbackslash}rangle\$ of dominating sets of \$G\$ such that any two consecutive dominating sets differ by the addition or deletion of one vertex, and no dominating set has size bigger than \$k\$. We first improve a result of Haas and Seyffarth, by showing that if \$k={\textbackslash}Gamma(G)+{\textbackslash}alpha(G)-1\$ (where \${\textbackslash}Gamma(G)\$ is the maximum size of a minimal dominating set and \${\textbackslash}alpha(G)\$ the maximum size of an independent set), then there exists a linear \{{\textbackslash}sf TAR\} reconfiguration sequence between any pair of dominating sets. We then improve these results on several graph classes by showing that the same holds for \$K\_\{{\textbackslash}ell\}\$-minor free graph as long as \$k {\textbackslash}ge {\textbackslash}Gamma(G)+O({\textbackslash}ell {\textbackslash}sqrt\{{\textbackslash}log {\textbackslash}ell\})\$ and for planar graphs whenever \$k {\textbackslash}ge {\textbackslash}Gamma(G)+3\$. Finally, we show that if \$k={\textbackslash}Gamma(G)+tw(G)+1\$, then there also exists a linear transformation between any pair of dominating sets.}, urldate = {2020-07-06}, author = {Bousquet, Nicolas and Joffard, Alice and Ouvrard, Paul}, month = jun, year = {2020}, note = {arXiv: 2006.16726}, keywords = {Computer Science - Data Structures and Algorithms, Computer Science - Discrete Mathematics}, }

@unpublished{rautenbach2020reconfiguring, title = {Reconfiguring dominating sets in minor-closed graph classes}, url = {http://arxiv.org/abs/2005.13844}, {\textbar}D'{\textbar}{\textbackslash}\}+c{\textbackslash}sqrt\{n\}\$. Conversely, for every hereditary class \$\{{\textbackslash}cal G\}\$ that has balanced separators of order \$n{\textbackslash}mapsto n{\textasciicircum}{\textbackslash}alpha\$ for some \${\textbackslash}alpha{\textless}1\$, we prove that there is some positive constant \$C\$ such that, if \$G\$ is a graph in \$\{{\textbackslash}cal G\}\$ of order \$n\$, and \$D\$ and \$D'\$ are two dominating sets in \$G\$, then \$D\$ \$k\$-transforms to \$D'\$ for \$k={\textbackslash}max{\textbackslash}\{ {\textbar}D{\textbar},{\textbar}D'{\textbar}{\textbackslash}\}+{\textbackslash}lfloor Cn{\textasciicircum}{\textbackslash}alpha{\textbackslash}rfloor\$.}, urldate = {2020-06-06}, author = {Rautenbach, Dieter and Redl, Johannes}, month = may, year = {2020}, note = {arXiv: 2005.13844}, keywords = {Mathematics - Combinatorics}, }

Ito, Takehiro, Kamiński, Marcin, Ono, Hirotaka, Suzuki, Akira, Uehara, Ryuhei, & Yamanaka, Katsuhisa (2020). Parameterized complexity of independent set reconfiguration problems. Discrete Applied Mathematics. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dam.2020.01.022
QCKEY74Y year__2020 venue_short__Discrete Applied Mathematics type__journalArticle "Combinatorial reconfiguration" "Fixed parameter tractability" "Graph algorithm" "Independent set"
Discrete Applied Mathematics
Discrete Applied Mathematics
BIB
@article{ito2020parameterized, title = {Parameterized complexity of independent set reconfiguration problems}, issn = {0166-218X}, url = {http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166218X20300317}, doi = {10.1016/j.dam.2020.01.022}, and imagine that a token is placed on each vertex in I0. Then, the token jumping problem is to determine whether there exists a sequence of independent sets which transforms I0 into Ir so that each independent set in the sequence results from the previous one by moving exactly one token to another vertex. Therefore, all independent sets in the sequence must be of the same cardinality. This problem is PSPACE-complete even for planar graphs with maximum degree three. In this paper, we first show that the problem is W[1]-hard when parameterized only by the number of tokens. We then give an FPT algorithm for general graphs when parameterized by both the number of tokens and the maximum degree. Our FPT algorithm can be modified so that it finds an actual sequence of independent sets between I0 and Ir with the minimum number of token movements. We finally show that one of the results for token jumping can be extended to a more generalized reconfiguration problem for independent sets, called token addition and removal.}, language = {en}, urldate = {2020-03-04}, journal = {Discrete Applied Mathematics}, author = {Ito, Takehiro and Kamiński, Marcin and Ono, Hirotaka and Suzuki, Akira and Uehara, Ryuhei and Yamanaka, Katsuhisa}, month = feb, year = {2020}, keywords = {Combinatorial reconfiguration, Fixed parameter tractability, Graph algorithm, Independent set}, }
link

Biniaz, Ahmad, Jain, Kshitij, Lubiw, Anna, Masárová, Zuzana, Miltzow, Tillmann, Mondal, Debajyoti, … Turcotte, Alexi (2019). Token Swapping on Trees. Retrieved from http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.06981
arXiv: 1903.06981
QCKEY74Y year__2019 type__manuscript "03D15, 05C05, 68R05" "Computer Science - Computational Complexity" "Computer Science - Data Structures and Algorithms"
BIB
@unpublished{biniaz2019token, title = {Token {Swapping} on {Trees}}, url = {http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.06981}, where a swap exchanges the tokens on the endpoints of an edge. Token swapping on a tree, also known as "sorting with a transposition tree", is not known to be in P nor NP-complete. We present some partial results: 1. An optimum swap sequence may need to perform a swap on a leaf vertex that has the correct token (a "happy leaf"), disproving a conjecture of Vaughan. 2. Any algorithm that fixes happy leaves---as all known approximation algorithms for the problem do---has approximation factor at least \$4/3\$. Furthermore, the two best-known 2-approximation algorithms have approximation factor exactly 2. 3. A generalized problem---weighted coloured token swapping---is NP-complete on trees, but solvable in polynomial time on paths and stars. In this version, tokens and vertices have colours, and colours have weights. The goal is to get every token to a vertex of the same colour, and the cost of a swap is the sum of the weights of the two tokens involved.}, urldate = {2019-05-14}, author = {Biniaz, Ahmad and Jain, Kshitij and Lubiw, Anna and Masárová, Zuzana and Miltzow, Tillmann and Mondal, Debajyoti and Naredla, Anurag Murty and Tkadlec, Josef and Turcotte, Alexi}, month = mar, year = {2019}, note = {arXiv: 1903.06981}, keywords = {03D15, 05C05, 68R05, Computer Science - Computational Complexity, Computer Science - Data Structures and Algorithms}, }
link
PDF

Yamanaka, Katsuhisa, Horiyama, Takashi, Keil, J. Mark, Kirkpatrick, David, Otachi, Yota, Saitoh, Toshiki, … Uno, Yushi (2018). Swapping colored tokens on graphs. Theoretical Computer Science, 729, 1–10. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tcs.2018.03.016
QCKEY74Y year__2018 venue_short__Theoretical Computer Science type__journalArticle "Colored token swapping" "Computational complexity" "Fixed-parameter algorithm" "NP-completeness" "Token swapping"
Theoretical Computer Science
Theoretical Computer Science
BIB
@article{yamanaka2018swapping, title = {Swapping colored tokens on graphs}, volume = {729}, issn = {0304-3975}, url = {http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304397518301774}, doi = {10.1016/j.tcs.2018.03.016}, we call this problem c-Colored Token Swapping since the current color of a vertex can be seen as a colored token placed on the vertex. We show that c-Colored Token Swapping is NP-complete for c=3 even if input graphs are restricted to connected planar bipartite graphs of maximum degree 3. We then show that 2-Colored Token Swapping can be solved in polynomial time for general graphs and in linear time for trees. Besides, we show that, the problem for complete graphs is fixed-parameter tractable when parameterized by the number of colors, while it is known to be NP-complete when the number of colors is unbounded.}, urldate = {2018-04-26}, journal = {Theoretical Computer Science}, author = {Yamanaka, Katsuhisa and Horiyama, Takashi and Keil, J. Mark and Kirkpatrick, David and Otachi, Yota and Saitoh, Toshiki and Uehara, Ryuhei and Uno, Yushi}, month = jun, year = {2018}, keywords = {Colored token swapping, Computational complexity, Fixed-parameter algorithm, NP-completeness, Token swapping}, pages = {1--10}, }

@unpublished{moore2018reconfiguration, title = {Reconfiguration of graph minors}, url = {http://arxiv.org/abs/1804.09240}, in which nodes represent \$H\$-models and two nodes are adjacent if their corresponding \$H\$-models differ by the label of a single vertex of \$G\$. Various operations on \$G\$ or \$H\$ are shown to preserve connectivity. In addition, we demonstrate properties of graphs \$G\$ that result in connectivity for the target graphs \$K\_2\$, \$K\_3\$, and \$K\_4\$, including a full characterization of graphs \$G\$ that result in connectivity for \$K\_2\$-models, as well as the relationship between connectivity of \$G\$ and other \$H\$-models.}, urldate = {2018-04-26}, author = {Moore, Benjamin and Nishimura, Naomi and Subramanya, Vijay}, month = apr, year = {2018}, note = {arXiv: 1804.09240}, keywords = {Computer Science - Data Structures and Algorithms, Computer Science - Discrete Mathematics, Mathematics - Combinatorics}, }

arXiv: 1803.03950
QCKEY74Y year__2018 type__manuscript "05C15" "Computer Science - Discrete Mathematics" "Mathematics - Combinatorics"
BIB
@unpublished{feghali2018paths, title = {Paths between colourings of sparse graphs}, url = {http://arxiv.org/abs/1803.03950}, 2016). Let \$d\$ and \$k\$ be positive integers, \$k {\textbackslash}geq d + 1\$. For every \${\textbackslash}epsilon {\textgreater} 0\$ and every graph \$G\$ with \$n\$ vertices and maximum average degree \$d - {\textbackslash}epsilon\$, there exists a constant \$c = c(d, {\textbackslash}epsilon)\$ such that \$R\_k(G)\$ has diameter \$O(n{\textasciicircum}c)\$. Our proof can be transformed into a simple polynomial time algorithm that finds a path between a given pair of colourings in \$R\_k(G)\$.}, urldate = {2018-03-19}, author = {Feghali, Carl}, month = mar, year = {2018}, note = {arXiv: 1803.03950}, keywords = {05C15, Computer Science - Discrete Mathematics, Mathematics - Combinatorics}, }

PDF
Vaidyanathan, Krishna (2017). Reconfiguring Graph Colorings (Master Thesis, University of Waterloo). Retrieved from https://uwspace.uwaterloo.ca/handle/10012/12251
QCKEY74Y year__2017 type__thesis ""
BIB
@mastersthesis{vaidyanathan2017reconfiguring, address = {Ontario, Canada}, title = {Reconfiguring {Graph} {Colorings}}, url = {https://uwspace.uwaterloo.ca/handle/10012/12251}, timetables, and compiler register allocation {\textbackslash}cite\{lewis2015guide\}. The most popular variant of graph coloring, k-coloring, can be thought of as an assignment of \$k\$ colors to the vertices of a graph such that adjacent vertices are assigned different colors. Reconfiguration problems, typically defined on the solution space of search problems, broadly ask whether one solution can be transformed to another solution using step-by-step transformations, when constrained to one or more specific transformation steps {\textbackslash}cite\{van2013complexity\}. One well-studied reconfiguration problem is the problem of deciding whether one k-coloring can be transformed to another k-coloring by changing the color of one vertex at a time, while always maintaining a k-coloring at each step. We consider two variants of graph coloring: acyclic coloring and equitable coloring, and their corresponding reconfiguration problems. A k-acylic coloring is a k-coloring where there are more than two colors used by the vertices of each cycle, and a k-equitable coloring is a k-coloring such that each color class, which is defined as the set of all vertices with a particular color, is nearly the same size as all others. We show that reconfiguration of acyclic colorings is PSPACE-hard, and that for non-bipartite graphs with chromatic number 3 there exist two k-acylic colorings \$f\_s\$ and \$f\_e\$ such that there is no sequence of transformations that can transform \$f\_s\$ to \$f\_e\$. We also consider the problem of whether two k-acylic colorings can be transformed to each other in at most \${\textbackslash}ell\$ steps, and show that it is in XP, which is the class of algorithms that run in time \$O(n{\textasciicircum}\{f(k)\})\$ for some computable function \$f\$ and parameter \$k\$, where in this case the parameter is defined to be the length of the reconfiguration sequence plus the length of the longest induced cycle. We also show that the reconfiguration of equitable colorings is PSPACE-hard and W[1]-hard with respect to the number of vertices with the same color. We give polynomial-time algorithms for Reconfiguration of Equitable Colorings when the number of colors used is two and also for paths when the number of colors used is three.}, language = {en}, urldate = {2020-08-07}, school = {University of Waterloo}, author = {Vaidyanathan, Krishna}, month = aug, year = {2017}, }
link
PDF
Haas, Ruth, & Seyffarth, Karen (2017). Reconfiguring dominating sets in some well-covered and other classes of graphs. Discrete Mathematics, 340(8), 1802–1817. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.disc.2017.03.007
QCKEY74Y year__2017 venue_short__Discrete Mathematics type__journalArticle "Graph domination" "Independent sets" "Reconfiguration problems"
Discrete Mathematics
Discrete Mathematics
BIB
@article{haas2017reconfiguring, title = {Reconfiguring dominating sets in some well-covered and other classes of graphs}, volume = {340}, issn = {0012-365X}, url = {http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012365X17300778}, doi = {10.1016/j.disc.2017.03.007}, number = {8}, urldate = {2017-04-26}, journal = {Discrete Mathematics}, author = {Haas, Ruth and Seyffarth, Karen}, month = aug, year = {2017}, keywords = {Graph domination, Independent sets, Reconfiguration problems}, pages = {1802--1817}, }
link
PDF
Mynhardt, C. M., Roux, R., & Teshima, L. E. (2017). Connected $k$-Dominating Graphs. Retrieved from http://arxiv.org/abs/1708.05458
arXiv: 1708.05458

Ito, Takehiro, Nooka, Hiroyuki, & Zhou, Xiao (2016). Reconfiguration of Vertex Covers in a Graph. IEICE Transactions on Information and Systems, E99.D(3), 598–606. https://doi.org/10.1587/transinf.2015FCP0010
QCKEY74Y year__2016 type__journalArticle "combinatorial reconfiguration" "even-hole-free graph" "graph algorithm" "vertex cover"
IEICE Transactions on Information and Systems
BIB
@article{ito2016reconfiguration, title = {Reconfiguration of {Vertex} {Covers} in a {Graph}}, volume = {E99.D}, url = {https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/transinf/E99.D/3/E99.D_2015FCP0010/_pdf/-char/en}, doi = {10.1587/transinf.2015FCP0010}, {\textbar}Ct{\textbar}\}. Then, the vertex cover reconfiguration problem is to determine whether there exists a sequence of vertex covers of G which transforms C0 into Ct such that each vertex cover in the sequence is of cardinality at most k and is obtained from the previous one by either adding or deleting exactly one vertex. This problem is PSPACE-complete even for planar graphs. In this paper, we first give a linear-time algorithm to solve the problem for even-hole-free graphs, which include several well-known graphs, such as trees, interval graphs and chordal graphs. We then give an upper bound on k for which any pair of vertex covers in a graph G has a desired sequence. Our upper bound is best possible in some sense.}, number = {3}, journal = {IEICE Transactions on Information and Systems}, author = {Ito, Takehiro and Nooka, Hiroyuki and Zhou, Xiao}, year = {2016}, keywords = {combinatorial reconfiguration, even-hole-free graph, graph algorithm, vertex cover}, pages = {598--606}, }
link

PDF
Yamada, Takeshi, & Uehara, Ryuhei (2016). Shortest Reconfiguration of Sliding Tokens on a Caterpillar. In Mohammad Kaykobad & Rossella Petreschi (Eds.), Algorithms and Computation: 10th International Workshop, WALCOM 2016, Kathmandu, Nepal, March 29-31, 2016, Proceedings (pp. 236–248). https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-30139-6_19
QCKEY74Y year__2016 type__conferencePaper ""
BIB
@inproceedings{yamada2016shortest, title = {Shortest {Reconfiguration} of {Sliding} {Tokens} on a {Caterpillar}}, url = {http://link.springer.com/10.1007/978-3-319-30139-6_19}, doi = {10.1007/978-3-319-30139-6_19}, and imagine that a token is placed on each vertex in {\textbar}I\_b{\textbar}. Then, the sliding token problem is to determine whether there exists a sequence of independent sets which transforms I\_b into I\_r so that each independent set in the sequence results from the previous one by sliding exactly one token along an edge in the graph. The sliding token problem is one of the reconfiguration problems that attract the attention from the viewpoint of theoretical computer science. The reconfiguration problems tend to be PSPACE-complete in general, and some polynomial time algorithms are shown in restricted cases. Recently, the problems that aim at finding a shortest reconfiguration sequence are investigated. For the 3SAT problem, a trichotomy for the complexity of finding the shortest sequence has been shown, that is, it is in P, NP-complete, or PSPACE-complete in certain conditions. In general, even if it is polynomial time solvable to decide whether two instances are reconfigured with each other, it can be NP-complete to find a shortest sequence between them. Namely, finding a shortest sequence between two independent sets can be more difficult than the decision problem of reconfigurability between them. In this paper, we show that the problem for finding a shortest sequence between two independent sets is polynomial time solvable for some graph classes which are subclasses of the class of interval graphs. More precisely, we can find a shortest sequence between two independent sets on a graph G in polynomial time if either G is a proper interval graph, a trivially perfect graph, or a caterpillar. As far as the authors know, this is the first polynomial time algorithm for the shortest sliding token problem for a graph class that requires detours.}, booktitle = {Algorithms and {Computation}: 10th {International} {Workshop}, {WALCOM} 2016, {Kathmandu}, {Nepal}, {March} 29-31, 2016, {Proceedings}}, publisher = {Springer International Publishing}, author = {Yamada, Takeshi and Uehara, Ryuhei}, editor = {Kaykobad, Mohammad and Petreschi, Rossella}, year = {2016}, pages = {236--248}, }
link
PDF

arXiv: 1611.09296

Yamanaka, Katsuhisa, Horiyama, Takashi, Kirkpatrick, David, Otachi, Yota, Saitoh, Toshiki, Uehara, Ryuhei, & Uno, Yushi (2015). Swapping Colored Tokens on Graphs. In Frank Dehne, Jörg-Rüdiger Sack, & Ulrike Stege (Eds.), Algorithms and Data Structures (pp. 619–628). https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-21840-3_51
QCKEY74Y year__2015 type__conferencePaper "Bipartite Graph" "General Graph" "Linear Time" "Maximum Degree" "Polynomial Time"
BIB
@inproceedings{yamanaka2015swapping, address = {Cham}, series = {Lecture {Notes} in {Computer} {Science}}, title = {Swapping {Colored} {Tokens} on {Graphs}}, isbn = {978-3-319-21840-3}, url = {https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-319-21840-3_51}, doi = {10.1007/978-3-319-21840-3_51}, we call this problem ccc -Colored Token Swapping since the current color of a vertex can be seen as a colored token placed on the vertex. We show that ccc -Colored Token Swapping is NP-complete for every constant c≥3c≥3c {\textbackslash}ge 3 even if input graphs are restricted to connected planar bipartite graphs of maximum degree 3. We then show that 222 -Colored Token Swapping can be solved in polynomial time for general graphs and in linear time for trees.}, language = {en}, booktitle = {Algorithms and {Data} {Structures}}, publisher = {Springer International Publishing}, author = {Yamanaka, Katsuhisa and Horiyama, Takashi and Kirkpatrick, David and Otachi, Yota and Saitoh, Toshiki and Uehara, Ryuhei and Uno, Yushi}, editor = {Dehne, Frank and Sack, Jörg-Rüdiger and Stege, Ulrike}, year = {2015}, keywords = {Bipartite Graph, General Graph, Linear Time, Maximum Degree, Polynomial Time}, pages = {619--628}, }

Ito, Takehiro, Nooka, Hiroyuki, & Zhou, Xiao (2015). Reconfiguration of Vertex Covers in a Graph. In Kratochvíl Jan, Mirka Miller, & Dalibor Froncek (Eds.), Combinatorial Algorithms (pp. 164–175). https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-19315-1_15
QCKEY74Y year__2015 type__conferencePaper ""
BIB
@inproceedings{ito2015reconfiguration, address = {Cham}, series = {Lecture {Notes} in {Computer} {Science}}, title = {Reconfiguration of {Vertex} {Covers} in a {Graph}}, isbn = {978-3-319-19315-1}, url = {https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-319-19315-1_15}, doi = {10.1007/978-3-319-19315-1_15}, {\textbar}Ct{\textbar}\}k≥max\{{\textbar}C0{\textbar},{\textbar}Ct{\textbar}\}k{\textbackslash}ge {\textbackslash}max {\textbackslash}\{{\textbackslash}left{\textbar} C\_0 {\textbackslash}right{\textbar} , {\textbackslash}left{\textbar} C\_t {\textbackslash}right{\textbar} {\textbackslash}\}. Then, the vertex cover reconfiguration problem is to determine whether there exists a sequence of vertex covers of G which transforms C0C0C\_\{0\} into CtCtC\_\{t\} such that each vertex cover in the sequence is of cardinality at most kkk and is obtained from the previous one by either adding or deleting exactly one vertex. This problem is PSPACE-complete even for planar graphs. In this paper, we first give a linear-time algorithm to solve the problem for even-hole-free graphs, which include several well-known graphs, such as trees, interval graphs and chordal graphs. We then give an upper bound on kkk for which any pair of vertex covers in a graph G has a desired sequence. Our upper bound is best possible in some sense.}, language = {en}, booktitle = {Combinatorial {Algorithms}}, publisher = {Springer International Publishing}, author = {Ito, Takehiro and Nooka, Hiroyuki and Zhou, Xiao}, editor = {Jan, Kratochvíl and Miller, Mirka and Froncek, Dalibor}, year = {2015}, pages = {164--175}, }
link

PDF
Yamada, Takeshi, & Uehara, Ryuhei (2015). Shortest Reconfiguration of Sliding Tokens on a Caterpillar. Retrieved from https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.00243v1
QCKEY74Y year__2015 type__manuscript ""
BIB
@unpublished{yamada2015shortest, title = {Shortest {Reconfiguration} of {Sliding} {Tokens} on a {Caterpillar}}, url = {https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.00243v1}, and imagine that a token is placed on each vertex in {\textbar}I\_b{\textbar}. Then, the sliding token problem is to determine whether there exists a sequence of independent sets which transforms I\_b into I\_r so that each independent set in the sequence results from the previous one by sliding exactly one token along an edge in the graph. The sliding token problem is one of the reconfiguration problems that attract the attention from the viewpoint of theoretical computer science. The reconfiguration problems tend to be PSPACE-complete in general, and some polynomial time algorithms are shown in restricted cases. Recently, the problems that aim at finding a shortest reconfiguration sequence are investigated. For the 3SAT problem, a trichotomy for the complexity of finding the shortest sequence has been shown, that is, it is in P, NP-complete, or PSPACE-complete in certain conditions. In general, even if it is polynomial time solvable to decide whether two instances are reconfigured with each other, it can be NP-complete to find a shortest sequence between them. Namely, finding a shortest sequence between two independent sets can be more difficult than the decision problem of reconfigurability between them. In this paper, we show that the problem for finding a shortest sequence between two independent sets is polynomial time solvable for some graph classes which are subclasses of the class of interval graphs. More precisely, we can find a shortest sequence between two independent sets on a graph G in polynomial time if either G is a proper interval graph, a trivially perfect graph, or a caterpillar. As far as the authors know, this is the first polynomial time algorithm for the shortest sliding token problem for a graph class that requires detours.}, language = {en}, urldate = {2019-11-18}, author = {Yamada, Takeshi and Uehara, Ryuhei}, month = nov, year = {2015}, }
link
PDF
Demaine, Erik D., Demaine, Martin L., Fox-Epstein, Eli, Hoang, Duc A., Ito, Takehiro, Ono, Hirotaka, … Yamada, Takeshi (2015). Linear-time algorithm for sliding tokens on trees. Theoretical Computer Science, 600, 132–142. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tcs.2015.07.037
QCKEY74Y year__2015 type__journalArticle "Combinatorial reconfiguration" "Graph algorithm" "Independent set" "Sliding token" "Tree"
Theoretical Computer Science
BIB
@article{demaine2015linear-time, title = {Linear-time algorithm for sliding tokens on trees}, volume = {600}, copyright = {All rights reserved}, issn = {03043975}, url = {http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304397515006829}, doi = {10.1016/j.tcs.2015.07.037}, and imagine that a token is placed on each vertex in Ib. Then, the sliding token problem is to determine whether there exists a sequence of independent sets which transforms Ib into Ir so that each independent set in the sequence results from the previous one by sliding exactly one token along an edge in the graph. This problem is known to be PSPACE-complete even for planar graphs, and also for bounded treewidth graphs. In this paper, we thus study the problem restricted to trees, and give the following three results: (1) the decision problem is solvable in linear time; (2) for a yes-instance, we can find in quadratic time an actual sequence of independent sets between Ib and Ir whose length (i.e., the number of token-slides) is quadratic; and (3) there exists an infinite family of instances on paths for which any sequence requires quadratic length.}, journal = {Theoretical Computer Science}, author = {Demaine, Erik D. and Demaine, Martin L. and Fox-Epstein, Eli and Hoang, Duc A. and Ito, Takehiro and Ono, Hirotaka and Otachi, Yota and Uehara, Ryuhei and Yamada, Takeshi}, month = oct, year = {2015}, keywords = {Combinatorial reconfiguration, Graph algorithm, Independent set, Sliding token, Tree}, pages = {132--142}, }
link

Mouawad, Amer E., Nishimura, Naomi, Raman, Venkatesh, Simjour, Narges, & Suzuki, Akira (2013). On the Parameterized Complexity of Reconfiguration Problems. Retrieved from http://arxiv.org/abs/1308.2409
arXiv: 1308.2409
QCKEY74Y year__2013 type__manuscript "Computer Science - Computational Complexity" "Computer Science - Data Structures and Algorithms"
BIB
@unpublished{mouawad2013parameterized, title = {On the {Parameterized} {Complexity} of {Reconfiguration} {Problems}}, url = {http://arxiv.org/abs/1308.2409}, used to obtain fixed-parameter algorithms for the reconfiguration versions of \{{\textbackslash}sc Vertex Cover\} and, more generally, \{{\textbackslash}sc Bounded Hitting Set\} and \{{\textbackslash}sc Feedback Vertex Set\}, all parameterized by \$k\$. In contrast, we show that reconfiguring \{{\textbackslash}sc Unbounded Hitting Set\} is \$W[2]\$-hard when parameterized by \$k+{\textbackslash}ell\$. We also demonstrate the \$W[1]\$-hardness of the reconfiguration versions of a large class of maximization problems parameterized by \$k+{\textbackslash}ell\$, and of their corresponding deletion problems parameterized by \${\textbackslash}ell\$; in doing so, we show that there exist problems in FPT when parameterized by \$k\$, but whose reconfiguration versions are \$W[1]\$-hard when parameterized by \$k+{\textbackslash}ell\$.}, urldate = {2020-02-23}, author = {Mouawad, Amer E. and Nishimura, Naomi and Raman, Venkatesh and Simjour, Narges and Suzuki, Akira}, month = aug, year = {2013}, note = {arXiv: 1308.2409}, keywords = {Computer Science - Computational Complexity, Computer Science - Data Structures and Algorithms}, }
link

PDF
Bonsma, Paul, & Cereceda, Luis (2009). Finding Paths between graph colourings: PSPACE-completeness and superpolynomial distances. Theoretical Computer Science, 410(50), 5215–5226. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tcs.2009.08.023
QCKEY74Y year__2009 venue_short__Theoretical Computer Science type__journalArticle "Colour graph" "PSPACE-complete" "Superpolynomial distance" "Vertex-recolouring"
Theoretical Computer Science
Theoretical Computer Science
BIB
@article{bonsma2009finding, series = {Mathematical {Foundations} of {Computer} {Science} ({MFCS} 2007)}, title = {Finding {Paths} between graph colourings: {PSPACE}-completeness and superpolynomial distances}, volume = {410}, issn = {0304-3975}, shorttitle = {Finding {Paths} between graph colourings}, url = {http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304397509006069}, doi = {10.1016/j.tcs.2009.08.023}, together with two k-colourings for each GN,k, such that the minimum number of recolouring steps required to transform the first colouring into the second is superpolynomial in the size of the graph: the minimum number of steps is Ω(2N), whereas the size of GN is O(N2). This is in stark contrast to the k=3 case, where it is known that the minimum number of recolouring steps is at most quadratic in the number of vertices. We also show that a class of bipartite graphs can be constructed with this property, and that: (i) for 4≤k≤6 planar graphs and (ii) for k=4 bipartite planar graphs can be constructed with this property. This provides a remarkable correspondence between the tractability of the problem and its underlying structure.}, number = {50}, urldate = {2017-07-25}, journal = {Theoretical Computer Science}, author = {Bonsma, Paul and Cereceda, Luis}, month = nov, year = {2009}, keywords = {Colour graph, PSPACE-complete, Superpolynomial distance, Vertex-recolouring}, pages = {5215--5226}, }
link
PDF
